links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{poem infobox | title=''The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains'' | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names=''Thoughts on Parade'',
''Swallow'',
''The Swallow and the Traveller on the Plains'' | written=After [[19 July]] of [[1915]] | revised=[[4 August]] of [[1915]] | published=''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Swallow|Swallows]] }} '''''The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains'''''{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/collected_poems_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien'' (2024) Arranged by Date|dated= 4 September 2025|website= HS|accessed= 29 December 2025|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, note to "p. 219, ll. 16–17:"{{CG|Po}}: "By Title", pp. 855 (entry "''The Swallow and the Traveller on the Plains''. Unpublished. Earlier called ''Thoughts on Parade''."), 856 (entry "''Thoughts on Parade'' see ''The Swallow and the Traveller on the Plains''") is "a series of rather dark thoughts"{{CP|Introduction}}, Introduction, pp. xxiv-xxv written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] on [[19 July]] of [[1915]] probably after his Army training began at Bedford.{{CG|C}}, p. 71 (entry "19 July 1915") == Poem excerpt == :O swallow, black swallow, I gazed up at thee :out of heat and dust and a great weariness; :bravely thou wert beating far aloft :under the sunless clouds in those great spaces :where thunder sits enchained and the winds are cavernously penned.{{CP|35}}, pp. 216-24 == Background == Sometime in the period from [[19 July]] to "about a month"{{CG|RG}}, p. 77 (entry "Bedford (Bedfordshire)") later in [[1915]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote the poem '''''Thoughts on Parade''''' after beginning his training for the Army "in a house…with half a dozen other officers"{{B|II}}, Chapter VII: War, p. 77 at Bedford. He probably initially wrote this poem, as well as ''[[Dark Are the Clouds about the North]]'',{{CP|38}}, p. 235 as a consequence of being unable "to come and go as he pleased" to see [[Edith Bratt]]. The poem was originally written in prose before Tolkien "divided it into lines". Sometime later, Tolkien made "trial workings" in one of his "poetry notebooks" to revise the poem. On [[4 August]], Tolkien further rewrote the poem, changing its name from ''Thoughts on Parade'' to '''''The Swallow and the Traveller on the Plains''''' or ''The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains''.{{CG|C}}, p. 72 (entry "4 August 1915") When revising the poem, Tolkien had written lines 48-9{{CP|35}}, p. 224 (note "B48-9:") on "a stray manuscript" draft containing the earliest workings of ''[[A Song of Aryador|The Pines of Aryador]]''.{{CP|37}}, p. 228 Sometime near "the end of 1915 or the start of [[1916]]", Tolkien included ''The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains'' as '''''Swallow''''' in parentheses as part a list of poems he compiled.{{CP|A3}}, p. 1381 (list "D") According to [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]], it is possible that the parentheses which Tolkien put the poem in meant that he was uncertain of including it in his list. In September [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 35 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' along with the earliest version. In their commentary to the first version, Hammond and Scull interpreted the name of the earlier version, ''Thoughts on Parade'', as referring to "the poet's thoughts…parading through his consciousness…while he is on parade…among an assembly of troops". In their commentary to the revised poem, Hammond and Scull suggested that, while the "[[Wikipedia:Black Swallow|black swallow]]" probably shouldn't be taken "too literally", such a bird did exist, though not in [[England]]. In a note on their "Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien''", Hammond and Scull note that, while "[[Christopher Tolkien]] read the title on the second manuscript with a comma", they "felt that the mark…was too indistinct to be certainly a mark of punctuation". However, since Tolkien never wrote "out the revised title" anywhere else, they did not have anything to compare to the writing on the second manuscript. == Inspiration == According to Hammond and Scull, Tolkien may have used a swallow in the poem because it was "a familiar, and seemingly fearless, migratory bird" and that "flocks of swallows historically tended to arrive in England in March or April" before leaving "in September or October" for southern Africa; this was "a long journey twice each year". Tolkien would later use the same imagery of "swallows singing in the eaves" in ''[[Dark Are the Clouds about the North]]''.{{CP|38}}, p. 240 Tolkien may have been using this as an allusion to how, while he "was only some sixty miles away from [[Edith Bratt]] in Warwick,…it was a 'long road' while he was bound by military law". Hammond and Scull also note that "the language and nature of Tolkien's poem" seems to "recall those of" [[Wikipedia:Alfred, Lord Tennyson|Alfred Tennyson]]'s ''[[Wikipedia:The Princess (Tennyson poem)|The Princess]]'', a poem that inspired [[Wikipedia:Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]'s "[[Wikipedia:List of poems by Samuel Taylor Coleridge#Something Childish, but very Natural. Written in Germany.|Something Childish, but Very Natural]]", which has "lines with a similar sentiment". {{References}} {{Poems}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains, The}} [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]]
